# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the Julia code that solves your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = "$word"
        else
            line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    return result * "\n" * line
end
```
This function splits the input string into words and checks if adding a new word to the current line would exceed the maximum width. If it does, it starts a new line with this word. The function then returns the final string with all lines separated by newline characters.

You can use this function like so:
```julia
s = "This is an example of wrapping text"
print(wrap_string(s))
```
The output will be:
```
This is an 
example of 
wrapping text
```
